Sure, here's a question for you: 

Calculate the standard enthalpy change ($\Delta H^\circ$) for the following reaction using Hess's Law.

$$\mathrm{2H_2(g) + O_2(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l)}$$

Given the following reactions and their respective $\Delta H^\circ$ values:

$$\mathrm{2H_2(g) + O_2(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(g)}\qquad\Delta H^\circ = -483.6\,\mathrm{kJ/mol}$$

$$\mathrm{2H_2O(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l)}\qquad\Delta H^\circ = -40.7\,\mathrm{kJ/mol}$$

Note: Ensure that the equations are properly balanced and specify the state of each substance.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change ($\Delta H^\circ$) for the target reaction using Hess's Law, we can combine the given reactions in such a way that the target reaction is obtained. In this case, the target reaction can be obtained by adding the given reactions together:

Target reaction:
$$\mathrm{2H_2(g) + O_2(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l)}$$

Given reactions:
1) $$\mathrm{2H_2(g) + O_2(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(g)}\qquad\Delta H^\circ_1 = -483.6\,\mathrm{kJ/mol}$$
2) $$\mathrm{2H_2O(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l)}\qquad\Delta H^\circ_2 = -40.7\,\mathrm{kJ/mol}$$

Add the given reactions together:
$$\mathrm{2H_2(g) + O_2(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(g) + 2H_2O(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l)}$$

Now, add the respective $\Delta H^\circ$ values together:
$$\Delta H^\circ_\text{target} = \Delta H^\circ_1 + \Delta H^\circ_2 = -483.6\,\mathrm{kJ/mol} + (-40.7\,\mathrm{kJ/mol}) = -524.3\,\mathrm{kJ/mol}$$

So, the standard enthalpy change ($\Delta H^\circ$) for the target reaction is -524.3 kJ/mol.
